multichart._comment1: This filter MUST be first and must use this name
multichart._comment2: The values are computed by the client.

help.default: This filter allows you to select: 1) the count or rate of cases screened-in for investigation/assessment on the first day of the quarter or year (point-in-time data) or 2) the count or rate of opened and closed investigations/assessments (cohort data). The ‘Overview’ selection shows the point-in-time data in the top bar graph and the cohort data in the bottom line graph.
help.sp_ihs_trends_counts: This filter allows you to select: 1) the count or rate of placement prevention service cases on the first day of the quarter or year (point-in-time data) or 2) the count or rate of opened and closed placement prevention cases by quarter or year (cohort data). The ‘overview’ selection shows the point-in-time data in the top bar graph and the cohort data in the bottom line graph.
help.sp_ooh_wb_familysettings: The graph format provides a line graph of the percentage of children in one of three family settings—a state foster home, a private foster home, or with relatives/kin—on the first day of the year (point-in-time data). The ‘overview’ displays the percentage of children in all family settings, as well as those in a ‘non-family setting (e.g., group home).
help.sp_ooh_wb_siblings_by_year: With filter you can examine whether all, some,or none of the siblings in family are placed together in out-of-home care. The‘overview’ selection compares the three choices.

display.help: Age references the child’s age at the time of placement in out-of-home care.
Age at exit references the age of the child when s/he left out-of-home care.
This filter references the child’s age when they entered out-of-home care.
Age references the child’s age on the first day of the year(s).

Age references the child’s age at the time s/he was removed from their home and placed into out-of-home care (e.g., kinship care, foster care). Because the age categories are based on U.S. Census classifications, we are able to calculate the rate of cases (per 1,000) by age for the state or county.

Age references the child’s age on a given date (i.e., the first day of the year or quarter). Because the age categories are based on U.S. Census classifications, we are able to calculate the rate of cases (per 1,000) by age for the state or county.

The age categories for children who exit out-of-homecare includes youth through the 18th year in order to account for all emancipations, which can continue through the 18th year. (Other age categories in the Data Portal end on the youth’s 18th birthday.)

This filter is used for the Investigations & Assessments and Placement Prevention Services measures. It references the ages of the children in the household at the time the referral was investigated/assessed or at the time the family was receiving placement prevention services. The age categories follow U.S. Census classifications, therefore we are able to calculate the rate of cases per 1,000 households.
You can select re-entry into out-of-home care from reunification, adoption, or guardianship. The default includes all three outcomes.

You can select one of three permanency outcomes (reunification, guardianship, or adoption), as well as emancipation, other exit (e.g., transfer to another authority), or still in out-of-home care. The default outcome/exit type includes reunification, adoption, and guardianship.
You can select exit from out-of-home care to reunification, adoption, guardianship, emancipation or other (e.g., transfer to another Washington State authority).
This filter returns data on the number of siblings in a family in order to assess the configuration of siblings who are placed together.
This filter returns data on the groupings (i.e., all, some, or none) of siblings placed in out-of-home care.
You can filter for relative/kinship placements only or for all types of placement (foster care, kinship care, group home, etc.).

Race and ethnicity categories are based on U.S. Census classifications. Races are above the line, ethnicities are below the line. Because the Census provides data on the races and ethnicities within geographic divisions, we are able to calculate the rate of cases (per 1,000) by race or ethnicity for the state or county.  Note that each household or child has a race AND an ethnicity.
This is the county where the referral was screened-in for investigation. You can select any of Washington State’s 39 counties; ‘All’ (the default) returns statewide data.

help.default: This filter provides counts and rates of children in their first placement setting on the first day of a given year or quarter (point-in-time data). For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and January 1, 2005, the data returned will include the first placement that falls within the episode that includes January 1, 2005. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_entries_rates: This filter provides counts and rates of cohorts or groups of children who entered (or exited) out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by their first placement setting. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and the cohort year 2010, the data returned will include the 2010 number or rate of entries (or the number of exits) for of all the children in out-of-home care who were initially placed in foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_exits: This filter provides counts and rates of cohorts or groups of children who entered (or exited) out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by their first placement setting. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and the cohort year 2010, the data returned will include the 2010 number or rate of entries (or the number of exits) for of all the children in out-of-home care who were initially placed in foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_entries_counts: This filter provides counts and rates of cohorts or groups of children who entered (or exited) out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by their first placement setting. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and the cohort year 2010, the data returned will include the 2010 number or rate of entries (or the number of exits) for of all the children in out-of-home care who were initially placed in foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_reentry: This filter provides counts of cohorts or groups of children who re-entered out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by initial placement type. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and 2010 as the exit (from out-of-home care) cohort year, the data returned will include the percent of re-entries for all the children in out-of-home care in 2010 whose first placement setting was foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_outcomes: This filter provides counts of cohorts or groups of children who exited out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by initial placement type. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and 2010 as the entry (into out-of-home care) cohort year, the data returned will include the percent of the selected outcome(s) for all the children in out-of-home care in 2010 whose first placement setting was foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.

help.default: This filter provides counts and rates of children in their longest placement setting on the first day of a given year or quarter (point-in-time data). For example, if you select ’foster care’ and January 1, 2005, the data returned will include the longest placement that falls within the episode that includes January 1, 2005. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_entries_rates: This filter provides counts and rates of cohorts or groups of children who entered (or exited) out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by their longest placement setting. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and the cohort year 2010, the data returned will include the 2010 number or rate of entries (or the number of exits) for of all the children in out-of-home care who were initially placed in foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_exits: This filter provides counts and rates of cohorts or groups of children who entered (or exited) out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by their longest placement setting. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and the cohort year 2010, the data returned will include the 2010 number or rate of entries (or the number of exits) for of all the children in out-of-home care who were initially placed in foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_flow_entries_counts: This filter provides counts and rates of cohorts or groups of children who entered (or exited) out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by their longest placement setting. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and the cohort year 2010, the data returned will include the 2010 number or rate of entries (or the number of exits) for of all the children in out-of-home care who were initially placed in foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_reentry: This filter provides counts of cohorts or groups of children who re-entered out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by longest placement type. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and 2010 as the exit (from out-of-home care) cohort year, the data returned will include the percent of re-entries for all the children in out-of-home care in 2010 whose longest placement setting was foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.
help.sp_ooh_outcomes: This filter provides counts of cohorts or groups of children who exited out-of-home care in a selected quarter or year by longest placement type. For example, if you select ‘foster care’ and 2010 as the entry (into out-of-home care) cohort year, the data returned will include the percent of the selected outcome(s) for all the children in out-of-home care in 2010 whose longest placement setting was foster care. See placement settings in the Glossary for more information.

display.help: Cohort data for household with children who are placed in out-of-home care after receiving placement prevention services are aggregated into ‘first’ and ‘all’ placement prevention cases. See Interpreting Type of Count.
where
Cohort data for counts and rates of children in out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’, ‘unique’, and ‘all’ children entering out-of-home care. See Interpreting Type of Count.
Cohort data for counts of children in out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’, ‘unique’, and ‘all’ children exiting out-of-home care. See Interpreting Type of Count.

Data for counts/rates of children in out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’ and ‘all’ stays in out-of-home care. ‘First Stays in Out-of-Home Care’ refers to the first ever stay/episode in out-of-home care; ‘All Stays in Out-of-Home’ includes all stays/episodes during the selected quarter or year. See Interpreting Type of Count.

Cohort data for children who are re-referred after the first investigation or who re-enter out-of-home care are aggregated into counts of unduplicated or unique re-referrals or re-entries and first or initial re-referrals or re-entries within the selected time interval. See Interpreting Type of Count.
Cohort data for children who re-enter out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’ and ‘unique’ exits from out-of-home care. See Interpreting Type of Count.
Cohort data for children who enter out-of-home care are aggregated into ‘first’ and ‘unique’ entries into out-of-home care. See Interpreting Type of Count.

Cohort data for households with children who are re-referred following a prior referral that was screened-in for investigation/assessment are aggregated into counts of ‘first’ and ‘all’ investigations/assessments. See Interpreting Type of Count.

Data for counts/rate of investigations/assessments are aggregated into ‘first,’ ‘unique,’ and ‘all’ investigations/assessments per household. ‘First Investigation/Assessment’ is the first ever referral that was screened in for investigation/assessment. ‘Unique Investigations/Assessments’ references the first investigation/assessment within a given time period. ‘All Investigations/Assessments’ includes all referrals that were screened-in for investigation/assessment during the selected quarter or year. See Interpreting Type of Count.
This references the length of time of the selected cohort (group) by quarter(s) or year(s).
This references the count or rate on the first day of the quarter(s) or year(s) selected.

In Washington State, anyone who has reasonable cause to believe that a child has suffered abuse or neglect can, in good faith, make a report (usually called a referral). Mandated reporters (above the line) are required by law to report concerns to the local Children’s Administration office or to law enforcement. Law Enforcement Officer includes Corrections Personnel.

Adults below the line are mandated to report if they are “residing with a child suspected to have been severely abused”. ‘Other’ reporters include the subject or the victim. ‘All’ includes all referrals, mandated or not.

Currently you can filter for six primary entry points in the child welfare system, i.e., first point of contact with Children’s Administration. Currently, the Data Portal returns data for:

1) Child Protective Services (CPS), which provides 24 hour, seven days a week intake, screening, and investigative services for reports/referrals of alleged child abuse and neglect;

2) Family Reconciliation Services (FRS), a voluntary program serving runaway adolescents and youth in conflict with their families;

3) Child and Family Welfare Services (CFWS), which provides both permanency planning and court-ordered services to children and families to mitigate the risk of abuse or neglect so that children are able to safely return to their home of origin;

4) Risk Only, a referral made when information collected gives reasonable cause to believe that risk or safety factors exist that place the child at imminent risk of serious harm;

5) Alternative Response System (ARS), a voluntary program for low-to-moderate risk families who were referred to CPS; and

6) Family Assessment Response (FAR), a new alternative pathway for accepted reports of low-to-moderate risk of child maltreatment.

During an investigation or assessment, social workers can record one (or more) allegation per case. If you are looking at a household level measure (Investigations & Assessments or Placement Prevention Services), allegations are counted per household. If you are examining an Out-of-Home Care measure, allegations are counted per child.

Maltreatment types fall into three broad categories: 1) physical abuse; 2) sexual abuse (which includes sexual exploration); and 3) neglect (which includes abandonment, negligent treatment, and medical neglect).

With the default ‘count type’ set to ‘all,’ a single household/child can be associated with more than one allegation. The filter choice ‘Any of the Above,’ returns a count of one allegation for each household/child. The filter choice ‘All (With or Without Allegation)’ means that cases with no allegations are also counted (as well as cases with multiple allegations per case). Neglect comprises the bulk of allegations.

An allegation finding means that, more likely than not, the Children’s Administration Child Protection Services (CPS) investigator determined that child abuse or neglect did occur. If you are looking at a household level measure (Investigations & Assessments or Placement Prevention Services), findings are counted per household. If you are examining an Out-of-Home Care measure, findings are counted per child.

Findings fall into three broad categories: 1) physical abuse; 2) sexual abuse (which includes sexual exploration); and 3) neglect (which includes abandonment, negligent treatment, and medical neglect).

With the default ‘count type’ set to ‘all,’ a single household/child can be associated with more than one finding. The filter choice ‘Any of the Above,’ returns a count of one finding for each household/child. The filter choice ‘All (With or Without Allegation Finding)’ means that cases with no finding are also counted (as well as cases with multiple findings per case).

help.default:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Entry & Exit Trends measures provide cohort counts and rates of out-of-home care entries, as well as cohort counts of exits for the selected quarter(s) or year(s). The ‘number of out-of-home care placements’ filter provides the option to examine entries and exits into out-of-home care for children who had one to five or more placements.

If, for example, you select the measure ‘Count of out-of-Home Care Entries,’ and filter for the year 2004 and ‘2 placements,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children in out-of-home care who had two placements within an episode that started any time in 2004. If there were more than one episode in 2004 with two placements, both will be counted.
help.sp_ooh_pit_counts:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Placement Trends measures provide point-in-time counts and rates of out-of-home care placements for the first day of the selected quarter(s) or year(s). The ‘number of out-of-home care placements’ filter provides the option to examine out-of-home care episodes for children who have had one to five or more placements.

If, for example, you select the measure 'Count of Children in Out-of-Home Care,' and filter for January 1, 2004 and ‘3 placements,' the data returned will indicate the number of children in out-of-home care who had three placements within the out-of-home care episode that included January 1, 2004.
help.sp_ooh_pit_rates:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Placement Trends measures provide point-in-time counts and rates of out-of-home care placements for the first day of the selected quarter(s) or year(s). The ‘number of out-of-home care placements’ filter provides the option to examine out-of-home care episodes for children who have had one to five or more placements.

If, for example, you select the measure 'Count of Children in Out-of-Home Care,' and filter for January 1, 2004 and ‘3 placements,' the data returned will indicate the number of children in out-of-home care who had three placements within the out-of-home care episode that included January 1, 2004.
help.sp_ooh_reentry:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Out-of-Home Safety measure provides cohort percentages of re-entries into out-of-home care by month since exiting care. The ‘number of out-of-home care placements’ filter provides the option to examine re-entries for children who had one to five or more placements.

If, for example, you filter for exit year 2004 and ‘2 placements,’ the data returned will indicate the percentage of children re-entering out-of-home care (by the number of months since exiting care in 2004) who had two placements within an episode that started any time in 2004. If there were more than one episode in 2004 with two placements, both episodes will be counted.
help.sp_ooh_outcomes:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Out-of-Home Outcomes measure provides cohort percentages of children who exited to reunification, adoption, or guardianship. The ‘number of out-of-home care placements’ filter provides the option to examine exits for children who had one to five or more placements.

If, for example, you filter for the entry year 2004 and ‘2 placements,’ the data returned will indicate the percentage of children by outcome (and by the number of months since entering care in 2004) who had two placements within an episode that started any time in 2004. If there were more than one episode in 2004 with two placements, both episodes will be counted.
help.sp_ooh_wb_familysettings:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Well-Being measures provide point-in-time data on placements in family settings and with siblings. The ‘number of out-of-home care placements’ filter provides the option to examine the number of placements in a family setting or with siblings for children who had one to five or more placements.

If, for example, you select the measure ‘Current Placement in Family Setting’ and filter for January 1, 2004 and ‘3 placements,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children placed in various settings, including family setting, who had three placements within the out-of-home care episode that included January 1, 2004.
help.sp_ooh_wb_siblings_by_year:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Well-Being measures provide point-in-time data on placements in family settings and with siblings. The ‘number of out-of-home care placements’ filter provides the option to examine the number of placements in a family setting or with siblings for children who had one to five or more placements.

If, for example, you select the measure ‘Current Placement in Family Setting’ and filter for January 1, 2004 and ‘3 placements,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children placed in various settings, including family setting, who had three placements within the out-of-home care episode that included January 1, 2004.
help.sp_ooh_wb_siblings_by_sibgroup:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Well-Being measures provide point-in-time data on placements in family settings and with siblings. The ‘number of out-of-home care placements’ filter provides the option to examine the number of placements in a family setting or with siblings for children who had one to five or more placements.

If, for example, you select the measure ‘Current Placement in Family Setting’ and filter for January 1, 2004 and ‘3 placements,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children placed in various settings, including family setting, who had three placements within the out-of-home care episode that included January 1, 2004.

help.default:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Entry & Exit Trends measures provide cohort counts and rates of out-of-home care entries, as well as cohort counts of exits. The ‘duration of out-of-home stay’ filter provides the option to examine the entries and exits into out-of-home care for children who had an episode that lasted: greater than seven days; greater than 60 days; greater than one year; or greater than two years.

If, for example, you select the measure ‘Count of Out-of-Home Entries,’ and filter for the year 2004 and ‘episode duration greater than 60 days,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children in out-of-home care who had an episode that started any time in 2004 that lasted longer than 60 days. If there were more than one episode in 2004 that lasted longer than 60 days, both episodes will be counted. (Note that episodes that last longer than 60 days will include episodes than lasted longer than seven days, and so forth.)
help.sp_ooh_pit_counts:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home,and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Placement Trends measures provide point-in-time counts and rates of out-of-home care placements for the first day of the selected quarter(s) or year(s). The ‘duration of out-of-home stay’ filter provides the option to examine out-of-home care episodes for children who had an episode that was: greater than seven days; greater than 60 days; greater than one year; or greater than two years.

If, for example, you select the measure 'Count of Children in Out-of-Home Care,' and filter for January 1, 2004 and ‘episode duration greater than one year,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children in out-of-home care who were in care longer than one year within the out-of-home care episode that included January 1, 2004. (Note that episodes that last longer than one year will include episodes than lasted longer than seven or 60 days and so forth.)
help.sp_ooh_pit_rate:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home,and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Placement Trends measures provide point-in-time counts and rates of out-of-home care placements for the first day of the selected quarter(s) or year(s). The ‘duration of out-of-home stay’ filter provides the option to examine out-of-home care episodes for children who had an episode that was: greater than seven days; greater than 60 days; greater than one year; or greater than two years.

If, for example, you select the measure 'Count of Children in Out-of-Home Care,' and filter for January 1, 2004 and ‘episode duration greater than one year,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children in out-of-home care who were in care longer than one year within the out-of-home care episode that included January 1, 2004. (Note that episodes that last longer than one year will include episodes than lasted longer than seven or 60 days and so forth.)
help.sp_ooh_reentry:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Out-of-Home Safety measure provides cohort percentages of re-entries into out-of-home care by month since exiting care. The ‘duration of out-of-home stay’ filter provides the option to examine re-entries for children who had an out-of-home care episode that lasted: greater than seven days; greater than 60 days; greater than one year; or greater than two years.

If, for example, you filter for exit year 2004 and ‘episode duration greater than 60 days,’ the data returned will indicate the percentage of children re-entering out-of-home care (by the number of months since exiting care in 2004) who had an episode that started any time in 2004 and lasted longer than 60 days. If there were more than one episode in 2004 that lasted longer than 60 days, both episodes will be counted. (Note that episodes that last longer than 60 days will include episodes than lasted longer than seven days, and so forth.)
help.sp_ooh_outcomes:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Out-of-Home Outcomes measure provides cohort percentages of children who exited to reunification, adoption, or guardianship. The ‘duration of out-of-home stay’ filter provides the option to examine exits for children who had been in an out-of-home care episode that lasted: greater than seven days; greater than 60 days; greater than one year; or greater than two years.

If, for example, you filter for entry year 2004 and ‘episode duration greater than 60 days,’ the data returned will indicate the percentage of children by outcome (and by the number of months since entering care in 2004) who had an episode that started any time in 2004 that lasted longer than 60 days. If there were more than one episode in 2004 that lasted longer than 60 days, both episodes will be counted. (Note that episodes that last longer than 60 days will include episodes than lasted longer than seven days, and so forth.)
help.sp_ooh_wb_familysettings:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Well-Being measures provide point-in-time data on placements in family settings and with siblings. The ‘duration of out-of-home stay’ filter provides the option to examine the number of placements in a family setting or with siblings for children who had been in an out-of-home care episode that lasted: greater than seven days; greater than 60 days; greater than one year, or greater than two years.

If, for example, you select the measure ‘Current Placement in Family Setting,’ and filter for ‘episode duration greater than one year,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children placed in various settings, including family setting, whose episode than included January 1, 2004 was longer than one year.( Note that episodes that last longer than 60 days will include episodes than lasted longer than seven days, and so forth.)
help.sp_ooh_wb_siblings_by_year:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Well-Being measures provide point-in-time data on placements in family settings and with siblings. The ‘duration of out-of-home stay’ filter provides the option to examine the number of placements in a family setting or with siblings for children who had been in an out-of-home care episode that lasted: greater than seven days; greater than 60 days; greater than one year, or greater than two years.

If, for example, you select the measure ‘Current Placement in Family Setting,’ and filter for ‘episode duration greater than one year,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children placed in various settings, including family setting, whose episode than included January 1, 2004 was longer than one year. (Note that episodes that last longer than 60 days will include episodes than lasted longer than seven days, and so forth.)
help.sp_ooh_wb_siblings_by_sibgroup:
Episodes or stays in out-of-home care start with a child’s removal from home and end with their return home (or to another permanent outcome). A child can be placed more than once within an episode, e.g., a child may first be placed in a foster home, and then in the care of a relative before reunification with a parent, which ends the episode.

The Well-Being measures provide point-in-time data on placements in family settings and with siblings. The ‘duration of out-of-home stay’ filter provides the option to examine the number of placements in a family setting or with siblings for children who had been in an out-of-home care episode that lasted: greater than seven days; greater than 60 days; greater than one year, or greater than two years.

If, for example, you select the measure ‘Current Placement in Family Setting,’ and filter for ‘episode duration greater than one year,’ the data returned will indicate the number of children placed in various settings, including family setting, whose episode than included January 1, 2004 was longer than one year.(Note that episodes that last longer than one year will include episodes than lasted longer than seven or 60 days and so forth.)

display.help: The courts become involved when there is a dependency proceeding or action. A dependent child is one who was abandoned, abused or neglected, or whose parents are incapable of adequately parenting. In this filter, ‘Immediate Dependency’ means a dependency petition was filed within 45 days of the start of the out-of-home episode and ‘Eventual Dependency’ means the petition was filed more than 45 days after the start of the episode.

Some placement prevention services are paid by Children’s Administration (CA) and some are not covered. Examples of paid services include case management and certain behavioral rehabilitation services. CA-paid services can be directly linked to a child or a family. Services that are not paid for by CA cannot be linked to a child or family; are purchased in bulk; or are provided by a service provider or any entity other than CA (e.g., health care, employment services).

Some placement prevention services are paid by Children’s Administration (CA) and some are not covered. Examples of paid services include case management and certain behavioral rehabilitation services. CA-paid services can be directly linked to a child or a family. Services that are not paid for by CA cannot be linked to a child or family; are purchased in bulk; or are provided by a service provider or any entity other than CA (e.g., health care, employment services).

The service categories above the line are primarily placement prevention services. The services below the line tend to be services for families with children in out-of-home care. More about the following services can be found in the Glossary: Family Focused Services, Therapeutic Services, Receiving Care, Family Home Placements, Behavioral Rehabilitation Services, Other Therapeutic Living Situations, Specialty Adolescent Services, Respite Care, Sexually Aggressive Youth, Adoption Support.

The services below are generally the services for families with children in receiving placement prevention services in the home. More about the following services can be found in the Glossary: Family Focused Services, Therapeutic Services, Receiving Care, Family Home Placements, Behavioral Rehabilitation Services, Other Therapeutic Living Situations, Specialty Adolescent Services, Respite Care, Sexually Aggressive Youth, Adoption Support.

The six Department of Social and Health Services (DSHS) budget categories include all the major placement prevention service budget categories. DSHS codes are provided for people familiar with Children’s Administration budget categories.

The entry cohort is that group of children who entered out-of-home care in the selected year(s). ‘Entry Cohort Year’ choices begin January 2000 and end on the most recent year for which we have data. The default date is set four years earlier than the most recent year and returns result for 48 months. If a year that was less than 48 ago is selected, the line graph and the data will be truncated.
The cohort entry year TODO

This filter allows you to follow households with at least one child involved in an investigation/assessment from 2006 to the most recent available data. Data on the percent of households with children re-referred are returned in three month increments for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year. If the selected year is less than 48 months in the past, the line graph and the data will be truncated.

This filter allows you to follow households that received placement prevention services from 2009 to the most recent available data. Data on the percent of households (with at least one child placed in out-of-home care) are returned in three month increments for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year. If the selected year is less than 48 months in the past, the line graph and the data will be truncated.

The exit cohort is that group of children who exited out-of-home care in the selected year(s). ‘Exit Cohort Year’ choices begin January 2000 to the most recent available data. Data on the percent of children who have re-entered out-of-home care are available in three month increments for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year. If the selected year is fewer than 48 months ago, the line graph and the data will be truncated.

This filter follows the cohort of households which received their (first) investigation/assessment within the cohort year(s) selected. Data on the percent of children re-referred are returned for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year.
Not used?

The exit cohort is that group of children who exited out-of-home care in the selected year(s). ‘Exit Cohort Year’ choices begin January 2000 and end on the most recent year for which we have data. The default date is set four years earlier than the most recent year and returns result for 48 months. If the selected year is less than 48 months in the past, the line graph and the data will be truncated.

This filter follows the cohort of households which received in-home services in the selected cohort year(s). Data on the percent of children placed in out-of-homecare are returned for up to 48 months following the selected cohort year.
The minimum and maximum date for which reliable data are available are indicated on the slide bar. You can adjust the bar to any range; the default is the full date range.
The minimum and maximum date for which reliable data are available are indicated on the slide bar. You can adjust the bar to any range; the default is the full date range.
Data for counts/rates of placement prevention service cases are aggregated into ‘first,’ ‘unique,’ and ‘all’ placement prevention service cases per household. See Interpreting Type of Count.
This is the county the data suggests the child lived in prior to removal. You can select any of Washington State’s 39 counties; ‘All’ (the default) returns statewide data.
This is the county the child was placed in on this date. You can select any of Washington State’s 39 counties; ‘All’ (default) returns statewide data.
The location of the child when s/he received a federal discharge (reunification, adoption, guardianship) or was emancipated (turned 18 years old).
The location of the child when s/he received a federal discharge (reunification, adoption, guardianship) or was emancipated (turned 18 years old).
This is the county where the referral was investigated/assessed. You can select any of Washington State’s 39 counties; ‘All’ (the default) returns statewide data.
This is the county where the placement prevention services were received. You can select any of Washington State’s 39 counties; ‘All’ (the default) returns statewide data.
